answers.answer: Have they ever ruled out MS or multiple sclerosis and ALS or Lou Gehrig's Disease?  Have they done an MRI of your brain & spine?  Have they checked your sciatic nerve?  Have you had any EMGs (electromyelograms) done?  What about circulation testing?  My grandma had peripheral vascular disease, something that can be hereditary and can show up as early as teen years.Regarding the head rocking- has anyone suggested essential tremor?  On wrong diagnosis' website, they suggest commonly undiagnosed concentration disorders can be a related medical area to essential tremor.   Have you had thorough testing by an ear, nose and throat specialist including your vestibular system?

HiWelcome to the MedHelp forum!There are several factors that should be investigated including spinal nerve compression, mini strokes, peripheral neuropathies as in diabetes and hypothyroidism, low Vit B 12, low Vit D, multiple sclerosis and abnormal levels of calcium, potassium, or sodium in your body. Please consult your PCP for preliminary tests.Hope this helps. Please let me know if there is any thing else and do keep me posted. Take care!

Thank you for your responsed. they are greatly appreciated. I have had an MRI in the past for the first time my leg went numb. they did not find anything wrong with me.  They claim i do not have diabetes or hypothyrodism. As far as the abnormal calcium, potassium, or sodium, i have had a few cases of low potassium when i had kidney stones. Kidney stones can also be from too much calcium, i do have alot of calcium build up under my fingernails. I dont know if maybe that means anything? I  cant see a doctor until i figure out my insurrance, i just recently moved from Ohio to South Carolina. So i havent got around to finding another doctor yet. I have been taking multivitamens  everyday, so im not sure if the low vit B12 and D would be a factor because i still have the problems with or without the vitamens. The one doctor mentioned maybe texting my sciatic nerve but being that i am so small, he didnt want to risk it. Ive been checked for circulation problems, there was none that they found... so i guess my best bet would be to figure out my insurance asap and find a doctor and see what they think down here. My left leg IS still currently numb :(  Thanks again for your responses :)

Also i didnt mention before because i wasnt sure that it would be a factor, but i do have stage two endometriosis as well and alot of the endometrial tissue was located  behind my uterus, would that maybe cause compression on the sciatic nerve?

Endometrial implants can sometimes be found in very unusual places, so I wouldn't rule out where it might be located in you, but I'm guessing it's pretty unlikely that would be the source of sciatic nerve compression.  I had severe endometriosis prior to my complete hysterectomy and some was on my bladder, which is somewhat unusual, but happens to some people.  During my hysterectomy, my bladder was found folded and stuck to my uterus with that sticky endometriosis after my first operation on endometriosis the previous year.  It sure was reaking havoc with my bladder function, let me tell you!

thanks for your response. sorry to hear that, that had to be very uncomfortable! i need to find a doctor around here, but im not sure about my insurrance still. My leg is still numb, yesterday was three weeks straight.

question: Hello. i posted this in another forum and have not received ANY responses, so i thought id try another forum.I am 20yr old Female. 107 Ibs. 5'6"I was wondering if anyone would have any ideas on what is causing my problems.Monday, February 8th, i woke up and my left leg, from my knee-cap all the way down to my ankle was completely numb.. i thought may have been the way i was sleeping or something.. but it is STILL just as numb to this day. (Feb 20)This is NOT the first time this has happend. In 2007 my right leg, from my hip to my knee-cap was completely numb for two weeks straight. then went away. My mother told me that i have had problems with this type of thing happening ever since i was real little as well. She told me that when i was two, both my legs did that at the same time and i couldnt walk for a month.I can walk fine now, i can move my legs and everything. Its just numb. Kind of a warm numbness.For as long as i can remember i also get RANDOM knee pain that feels like a "stabbing" pain that lasts for about 5 minutes. That happens once every half a year to a year. And i get horrible Hip pain (both sides) almost everyday. Occasionally bad enough on the left side to where it makes me limp for a few minutes. And the SLIGHT head movements. For example if im trying to concentrate or listen, my head will slightly rock back and forth, not enough for other people to really notice, but enough to where it isnt normal.I would assume this has something to do with a neurological problem... so if anyone has any ideas on What exactally that problem could possibly be. Please let me know. Thanks.
title: Recurring Leg Numbness
